title: Between 27 February 2022 and 27 August 2022, will Russia be restricted or banned from access to the SWIFT banking system?
preds: "[W]e will disconnect seven designated Russian entities (and their designated Russia-based subsidiaries) and three Belarusian entities (and their designated Belarus-based subsidiaries) from the SWIFT network. These Regulations require us to disconnect the identified Russian entities on 12 March 2022 and the identified Belarusian entities on 20 March 2022, and we will do so accordingly." - https://www.swift.com/news-events/news/message-swift-community (thanks, @monicaflorio, for the  source link)

I suspect that today's public announcement that the UAE will increase oil production may be of some comfort for the Germans, who have been reluctant - for good reason- to drop the axe on Russian oil and gas. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-03-09/germany-is-stalling-eu-efforts-to-broaden-russia-s-swift-ban

If Russia continues to kill Ukrainian civilians, restricting access to SWIFT will be another tool the international community can use to pressure Putin to back off. In fact, Swift made the following announcement on March 1:  "To this end, in compliance with the legal instruction in  EU Council Regulation (EU) 2022/345 of 1 March 2022, we will disconnect seven designated Russian entities (and their designated Russia based subsidiaries) from the SWIFT network. This Regulation requires us to disconnect the identified entities on 12 March 2022, and we will do so accordingly."  https://www.swift.com/news-events/news/message-swift-community

It looks like this will be determined March 12th when Swift actually enacts the block on seven Russian banks:
https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/eu-excludes-seven-russian-banks-swift-official-journal-2022-03-02/
the media news have already reported that this proposal has already been resolved positively. swift system took Russia away from its bennefits.
Non-oil & gas SWIFT transactions for banks close to the Russian regime will likely be banned.
The banking will be blocked as much as possible but it will not be closed completely.  The supply of Oil and Gas is at stake.
Current SWIFT-sanctions turn out to be insufficient. SBER bank and Gazprombank will sooner or later be included in SWIFT-sanctions.
Hasn't this happened? What am I missing?

It did happen, but partially  (some banking services linked to gas exports are operational). I expect that some of those SWIFT - related restrictions would be lifted until the end of May, following the truce at some point. However, it will still have some kind of a soft ban even then, which could be prolonged until Putin remains the President.
Well this has happened! So you better believe it will happen.
Most  likely yes at least to some restrictions

Has already been partly restricted. (+100%) Iran was banned from Swift in 2012, as part of sanctions over its nuclear program. It lost almost half of its oil export revenues and 30% of foreign trade. It Russia were to act in a fashion to withdraw from Ukraine, Russia would be reinstated for Europeans energy considerations. (-50%) Variable is Putin's actions to withdraw. Low probability of Putin taking action to avoid this. (+10%)  Main variable would be the probability of Putin removal by his inner circle.  (-30%) Net probability of yes is 80%

I believe it is not if, but when Russia will be blocked from the SWIFT system. This because Putin has brought nuclear language into the conversation. SWIFT appears to be the diplomatic equivalent of a nuclear option.

Based on what we know, it seems it's a question of the day/hour for Russia to be banned from SWIFT (https://www.reuters.com/business/swift-says-it-its-examining-which-entities-are-subject-sanctions-2022-03-01/). However, banning from SWIFT might not be as powerful as many believe (https://theconversation.com/swift-ejecting-russia-is-largely-symbolic-heres-why-178065)
Russia will be a pariah in the international banking community.
Isn't this closed as it has already happened?
The Germans are showing themselves to be against that
It is the only serious option available to the Western Powers and long term will be efective

The real sanctions are when you hit hard ............ this is one major body blow which should be exercised. Gradual progression / implementation is acceptable starting with some leading banks and the Central Bank.
Yes they will be restricted or banned until the situation with the Ukraine resolves.
Short time frame of forecast. Even August is too close to logistics window of the withdrawal necessary for global financial community to allow Russia access to SWIFT network
There will be some form of ban but it will not be complete—there will be loop holes to allow for Petroleum transactions

Some of Russian banks have now 2/28/22 been barred from SWIFT.  It appears that the corrupt English banks or corrupt banks with English people on their boards, for the purposes of money laundering and profit, are the obstacle to extending the ban in full.

At the end Russia will not be banned from SWIFT Access because the European energy supply of the Russian federation with gas and oil is too important for European countries, that they not will banning Russia from SWIFT
Biden has made announcements that these are coming
The US controls the sanctions and they suffer from Russophobia and greed.
As one of few visible demonstration of non lethal cooperative sanctions available, this provides a strong signal that the west is prepared to apply a wide ranging measure jointly.
It’s Monday and it is already being discussed.
Some Russian institutions are restricted now (I believe the media).
They may push this forward then retreat if Russia counters with gas cutoffs.
This has to happen as it has become well known due to media coverage
Seems inevitable at this point. Russia can't do enough, quickly enough, to avoid this consequence for invading Ukraine.
It's already been announced publically, but I'm not sure when it actually counts...However, I believe it will be pretty swift.
This is the whole country not just the people controlling the war if Putin does not deescalate then yes …
This question should have been posted at least 4 weeks ago.

Confirmation that banning certain Russian institutions from SWIFT is underway (https://uawire.org/kyiv-full-consensus-for-disconnecting-russia-from-swift-has-been-achieved-the-process-has-begun#). If the question were over a shorter timeline, my percentage would be lower. The move to ban Iran from SWIFT in 2012 officially started with a proposal on February 17, 2012, and wasn't approved until March 23rd, 2012 (https://www.eumonitor.eu/9353000/1/j9vvik7m1c3gyxp/viy85f9hbsyp). So even though it seems that all the EU countries are on board concerning the targeted removal of Russian institutions from SWIFT, it could still be some time before sanctioning happens. That being said, though, the Iranian sanctions seemed to have taken a lot longer up to this point. Perhaps SWIFT will move against Russia faster than it/EU did against Iran.

Judging from the date of the joint announcements, I guess this question will be voided, too. https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/STATEMENT_22_1423
https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2022/02/26/joint-statement-on-further-restrictive-economic-measures/

https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-business-europe-european-union-704b3b6678c5d23bd05482c89a0384d2
Looks like this is in the works, at least for a few banks.  Running out of bourbon here, though.

https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2022/02/26/joint-statement-on-further-restrictive-economic-measures/
i also predict unpredictable outcomes as a result.
A partial ban seems likely and is probably something Germany could stomach.
They will pull out all the stops short of direct intervention and this is one of those stops

The question says, "A SWIFT ban on one or more Russian institutions would count." Germany's "targeted & functional" exclusion of Russia may mean not banning everything with the "RU" code but only specific people, institutions, etc. I think Europe is almost there, and I suspect the US would end up supporting that, too.

Prior to night 2 in the Ukraine, the consensus was no. But Chancelor Scholz has given the go ahead for the resale of German artillery in to war zones and apperars to have weighed the short to medium term costs financial costs to Germany with the long term costs related to the stability of Europe.

I believe it is highly likely that Russia could be banned from SWIFT. However, given it has only been a few days into the conflict, there will likely still be very significant changes in the course of the conflict.

Financial sanctions appear at the moment to be the most important prong of the wests response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Unless either the current sanctions are enough to deter Putin (seems very unlikely), the west will be forced to either step up sanctions, increase support for Ukraine, or become more directly involved in the conflict. With a SWIFT ban/restriction already being discussed it seems likely that this would be a logical escalation of the sanctions (even if more targeted that a full ban). I am leaving a 10% margin of uncertainty for possible cases of either Russia backing down before the changes to sanction are needed or if an important ally demands a different approach taken due to internal reasons.

I'm unsure if this is official, but Russia's actions will result in widespread financial sanctions and worldwide bans from financial instruments.  These are likely to directly impact Russia's leaders as well as align with most nations interests as opposed to direct military action.
Shutting Russia off from Swift would be incredibly stupid, but that's why I'm giving it a 70% chance.

Banning Russia from SWIFT would be a huge step, and from my understanding would complicated financial transactions with Russia writ large. Restricting would be more feasible, but European countries are already balking on some of the sanctions that were originally proposed. Walking back the sanctions is completely understandable (though regrettable) based on their dependence on some key Russian sectors. Additionally, I'm not aware of any previous country being banned or restricted from using SWIFT. I'll do a little more research on this and come back with a better prediction. I am aware there is a lot of talk about this. But from what I am reading we are talking targeting people/businesses in Russia, not Russia as a whole.
Foreign Minister Kuleba reports that the process to disconnect #Russia from #SWIFT has begun.
Pretty sure this question will be voided like the question about the US sanctioning Putin and Lavrov.

Restrictions to the SWIFT system is a tough sanction but Russia already knows the West has this card in their hands.  Compared to 2014, Russia is now very sophisticated in usage of cryptocurrencies and cyberattacks which can compensate for any restrictions on SWIFT.

There were 4 EU countries opposing that, namely Germany, Italy, Hungary, and Cyprus. Cyprus seems to no more: https://twitter.com/DmytroKuleba/status/1497496218359898116 I have read similar reports today that Italy and Hungary have also removed their objections. And here are the updates on Germany: 
https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2022/feb/26/russia-ukraine-latest-news-fighting-kyiv-zelenskiy-assault-putin-capital?page=with:block-621a6c808f08219c41a737b2#block-621a6c808f08219c41a737b2 https://twitter.com/germanyintheeu/status/1497629293937049606

Some form of "restriction" is essentially guaranteed at this point and momentum is strongly in this direction. "Restriction" I put at 100%, "ban" I would be less certain about. It makes sense at the moment to inflict maximum pain on Russia, but I'm also concerned this will lead to Russian+Chinese integration down the line which is scary to think about

The EU would be punishing itself more than Russia if it did this. The United States imports 800k bpd of oil from Russia. How is the US going to pay for it, or would Americans pay $8 a gallon for gas? You can still do financial transactions by fax machine and phone, but the real risk is that Russia would counteract by cutting off energy supplies.  Swift is pretty much an all or nothing system. They can't grant you partial access. On what basis would they choose to restrict only certain Russian banks? There are already sanctions on Iranian oil. Cut out Russian energy as well, and the Biden administration is restricting oil production in the US, and prices skyrocket.  It's great for China and India though, because then they can buy Russian energy cheap. China and India both abstained from the vote to condemn Russia in the UN. Germany seems to be trying to find a way to do only a partial Swift restriction because they are very dependent on Russian energy, but there really is no way to do a partial ban. Germany has tried to have so much of it energy be renewable that it is very dependent on external countries for reliable energy. They can buy nuclear power from France for their grid, but Germans would still be paying at the pump.

The sanctioneers seem to be targeting one or a few institutions at a time.  They'll probably do one or more in the next few weeks, so I suppose I'm too low.  Almost everything is too weird to be 100% sure of, though.

I think this could happen within the next two -three days as European negotiations for further sanctions and aid gain support. Reality has dawned that Putin will have already factored in conventional sanctions and far more wide ranging unilateral efforts are starting to be debated.
